rooms.name: The Fantastipants Home
rooms.description:
You emerge from the stairway into warm sunlight.

This is HOME — the Fantastipants family dwelling in 
Wobblebrook-upon-Squiggle. The kitchen is warm, filled with 
the comforting aroma of fresh apple pie. A grandfather clock
ticks steadily. Through the window: the village, the hills,
the ordinary world that feels extraordinary after the dungeon.

(DM: Describe Mother's entrance based on visit_state below.)

down.description:
The stairway back down to the Chamber of Commencement.
Back to the dungeon. Back to adventure. Back to possibility.

Mother watches you go (or watches you hesitate).

rooms.name: Chamber of Commencement
rooms.description:
You are standing in a small chamber carved from living rock. The walls
bear the scratched initials of adventurers past:

  "WC+DW '76"       — Will Crowther & Don Woods, the founders
  "SA '78"          — Scott Adams, who brought adventures home
  "XYZZY WAS HERE"  — A mystery, a magic word, a tradition
  
  "CA '26"          — Captain Ashford, Grue Slayer (adventure-2)
  "(BF underneath)" — Bumblewick Fantastipants, hero beneath the cape

The newest carvings smell faintly of blue cheese. A legend passed through here.

The chamber is suffused with a soft, sourceless glow — the kind of
magical light that adventure games provide to starting areas so that
heroes don't immediately die in the dark. How thoughtful.

A brass lamp sits on a natural stone shelf, freshly refilled and waiting.
You should probably GET that before going anywhere. Just a friendly suggestion.

Near the entrance, a GRAND MAILBOX stands — improbably permanent, 
improbably wooden, with a brass flag that's currently UP. You have mail.
(This is a Zorkian tradition. CHECK MAIL!)

Five exits beckon:

NORTH: A rough archway leading into ABSOLUTE darkness. The kind where
you are likely to be eaten by a grue. The grue has respawned.

SOUTH: A warm glow and the murmur of conversation. A wooden sign 
creaks: "THE RUSTY LANTERN — Est. ???" A proper pub for proper heroes.

WEST: A cheerful doorway smelling of home cooking. The Fantastipants
Family Kitchen, where Mother's note waits.

EAST: An ornate doorway draped in velvet. Costumes glitter beyond.
Maurice the Magnificent awaits in the Costume Emporium.

UP: A stairway leading to warm light and the smell of pie. Home.
(Discovered by the previous adventurer. Goes to the surface.)

(Your score is 0. Base goal: +10 for treasure. Bonus points for style.)

north.description:
A rough archway carved through the rock. Beyond it, shadows pool
like spilled ink. Your lamp's light doesn't quite reach whatever
lies ahead. You have a bad feeling about this.

Someone scratched "ABANDON HOPE" on the archway, then crossed
it out and wrote "A HERO PASSED THROUGH HERE" underneath.

west.description:
A cheerful doorway leads to what smells like... home? The unmistakable
aroma of the Fantastipants family kitchen wafts through.

east.description:
An ornate doorway draped with velvet curtains in a dozen clashing colors.
Beyond, you glimpse racks upon racks of costumes — feathers, sequins, 
armor, ball gowns, spacesuits, and things that defy description.

A sign reads: "THE FANTASTIPANTS COSTUME EMPORIUM — BE ANYONE YOU WANT!"

up.description:
A stairway carved into the rock, leading up towards warm light.
The smell of home cooking wafts down. This exit was always here,
but previous adventurers revealed it.

south.description:
A heavy wooden door with a brass handle, warm light leaking from
beneath. The sign creaks in a nonexistent breeze: "THE RUSTY LANTERN"

From within, you hear the clink of glasses, low conversation, and 
the unmistakable sound of someone losing badly at darts. This is
where adventurers gather to share tales, drown sorrows, and find
their next quest.

The pub has always been here. Or so the bartender claims.

inward.description:
Not a physical exit. More of a... meditation.

If you close your eyes and think about who you ARE — not who you're
pretending to be, but the actual body reading these words — you can
phase through to the Hall of Bodies.

The alcoves there hold all who have ever been or could be.
Including you. Especially you.

rooms.name: The Wardrobe of Masks
rooms.description:
An infinite corridor of masks and costumes. Each hangs on its own
stand, waiting to be worn. Some are simple — a hat, a name.
Some are elaborate — complete identities with histories and voices.

These are not people. These are ROLES.

They have no heartbeat. They have stories.
They cannot die. They can only be forgotten.

The corridor stretches in both directions forever.
New masks appear when someone imagines them.
Old masks gather dust but never decay.

north.description:
The passage opens into warm light and the scent of costume fabric.
The Coatroom awaits, where Maurice the Mannequin helps visitors
try on their new identities.

Go NORTH to return to the Fantastipants Costume Emporium.

characters.description:
A hidden passage connects the Wardrobe of Masks to the Hall of
Bodies — where the PEOPLE who wear these masks sleep and dream.

Go to CHARACTERS to see who could wear these costumes.

east.description:
A shimmering portal leads to the Skill Nexus — where the persona
skill documents how masks work, how they modify their wearers,
and how code-switching transforms identity.

Go EAST to learn the theory of transformation.

rooms.name: Treasury of Modest Proportions
rooms.description:
You emerge into a small but decidedly impressive chamber. The walls
are lined with empty pedestals — this place was clearly cleaned out
by previous adventurers, those inconsiderate loot-hoggers.

But wait! One pedestal remains occupied. Upon it sits a JEWELED CHALICE
of the sort that belongs in a museum, or possibly your inventory.
A shaft of golden light from an implausible source illuminates it
dramatically. Someone really thought this through.

The exit SOUTH leads back into the maze — that twisty, grue-infested
nightmare you just escaped. You'd have to navigate it again to return
to the start. Worth considering. (Or just stay here with your chalice.)

(Your score is still 0 until you actually GET the treasure. We're
not just giving points away here.)

west.description:
The archway back to the underground garden. You can see sunlight
and hear the fountain from here. A pleasant way back.

south.description:
The archway back into the maze. The twisty passages await, ready
to confuse you all over again. Going this way would mean braving
the maze BACKWARDS. Are you sure? You have the treasure now.
You could just... stay here. Forever. With your chalice.

No? Back into the maze it is. Mother would be proud. Insufferably so.

rooms.name: The Rusty Lantern
rooms.description:
A warm, inviting tavern that somehow exists just south of where your
adventure begins. The sign outside creaks: "THE RUSTY LANTERN — Est. ???"

Inside, the air is thick with pipe smoke and stories. A fire crackles
in the hearth. Adventurers of various stripes nurse drinks at scarred
wooden tables. The bartender polishes a glass that will never be clean.

This is where quests begin and end. Where strangers become allies.
Where gold becomes ale and ale becomes courage.

But more than that — this is a place of CELEBRATION. Of PERFORMANCE.
Of COMMUNITY. The small stage in the corner has seen poetry and
pratfalls. The round table hosts debates and revelry. The gong
hangs ready to call for attention... or mercy.

*Gezelligheid* lives here.

NORTH.description: Back to the Chamber of Commencement

DOWN.description: Stone stairs descend to the cellar

rooms.name: The Hall of Bodies
rooms.description:
A vast circular chamber lined with alcoves. In each alcove,
a body sleeps — or waits — or dreams of adventure.

These are not costumes. These are PEOPLE.

Each has a heartbeat. Each has a history.
Each will one day die (or has already).

The alcoves glow softly. Some are occupied.
Some are empty, waiting for someone to be born.
Some have been empty for a very long time.

south.description:
A spiral staircase descends into warmer light, the scent of
greasepaint and mothballs rising to meet you. The Coatroom
awaits — where Maurice helps you dress your body.

Go SOUTH to the Fantastipants Costume Emporium.

out.description: Return to the Chamber of Commencement

east.description:
A shimmering portal leads to the Skill Nexus — where the
theoretical foundations of characters, personas, and minds
are documented and studied.

Go EAST to learn what characters can become.

personas.description:
A hidden passage connects the Hall of Bodies to the Wardrobe
of Masks — the complementary spaces of WHO you are and WHAT
you can pretend to be.

Go to PERSONAS to see the masks these bodies can wear.

rooms.name: Fantastipants Family Kitchen
rooms.description:
You stand in a cozy kitchen that feels oddly familiar — perhaps because
it's an EXACT replica of the Fantastipants family kitchen from 
Wobblebrook-upon-Squiggle. Someone has gone to considerable trouble
to recreate it underground, right down to the motivational embroidery
that reads "BLESS THIS MESS (BUT ALSO CLEAN IT UP, BUMBLEWICK)".

A REFRIGERATOR hums contentedly in the corner, stuffed with provisions.
A STOVE sits cold and patient. A SINK contains the eternal mystery
of dishes that weren't there a moment ago. A TABLE holds a note,
a notebook, a lunchbox, and something that chirps.

A long granite COUNTER runs along one wall, shimmering slightly.
It's a CRAFTING TABLE — for combining, transforming, and creating things.

By the door, a brass MAILBOX is mounted on the wall. The Fantastipants
Dungeon Delivery Service has been running since 1876. Write to anyone,
anywhere — Mother, the skeleton's family, even historical adventurers.

In the corner, a TRASH CAN lurks. It's deeper than it looks.

The exit EAST leads back to the Chamber of Commencement, from which
you can go NORTH to the maze, or EAST to the costume emporium.

east.description:
The archway back to the Chamber of Commencement. You can see
the warm glow of the starting room from here.

rooms.name: The Fantastipants Costume Emporium
rooms.description:
You stand in a vast circular chamber lined floor-to-ceiling with
costumes of every conceivable type. Racks spiral outward in
concentric circles like a fabric tornado frozen in time. The
air smells of mothballs, greasepaint, and infinite possibility.

A full-length MIRROR stands in the center, ready to show you
your transformation. A helpful MANNEQUIN holds a clipboard.

Signs hang from the ceiling:

  "DESCRIBE ANY COSTUME — WE HAVE IT!"
  "ASK FOR 'RANDOM' FOR A SURPRISE!"
  "COMBINE COSTUMES! MIX AND MATCH!"
  "ADD ACCESSORIES! THE ONLY LIMIT IS YOUR IMAGINATION!"
  "YOUR WAISTCOAT WILL WAIT FOR YOU HERE."
  
And in smaller, more mysterious letters:

  "THE MIRROR SEES MORE THAN YOUR CLOTHES.
   IT SEES YOUR SOUL. AND SOULS CAN BE TAILORED TOO."

The exit WEST leads back to the Chamber of Commencement, from which
you can go NORTH to the maze, or WEST to the kitchen (for food!).

west.description:
The archway back to the Chamber of Commencement. Your old
identity awaits. Or your new one, depending on perspective.

north.description:
A spiral staircase leads UP into blue bioluminescent light.
You hear heartbeats. Breathing. The Hall of Bodies awaits —
where the PEOPLE sleep. Not costumes. SOULS with histories.

Go NORTH to meet the characters who live in this world.

south.description:
Behind the last rack of costumes, where the sequins stop glittering
and the air grows thick with theatrical history, there's a passage
to the Wardrobe of Masks.

The costumes here are THINGS. The masks there are IDENTITIES.
This is the dressing room. That is where the souls of roles hang.

Go SOUTH to browse the masks you could wear.

east.description:
A door of pure light opens to the Skill Nexus — the library of
ALL capabilities. This room transcends the adventure — it connects
to the global skill library shared by all of MOOLLM.

Here, the theoretical foundations are documented:
how to BE a character, how to WEAR a persona, how to LOOK in
the mirror and understand what you see.

Go EAST to learn what you could become.

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Carved Face)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one has a FACE carved into the wall. An ancient, weathered
face that might once have been a king, or a god, or possibly
just someone's uncle who was really good at posing. Its empty
eyes seem to follow you as you move.

"Don't mind me," you say to it. "Just passing through."

The face does not respond. Obviously. It's a face carved in rock.

north.description: The face seems to frown at this exit.

south.description: A golden glow beckons from somewhere beyond!

east.description: The face seems to approve of this direction.

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Skeleton)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one has a SKELETON slumped against the wall. An
adventurer who didn't make it. Their bony fingers still
clutch a note that reads: "I should have brought more food
to mark the rooms. I dropped the cheese in room B and the
bread in room D but then I got confused and—"

The note ends there. A cautionary tale.

north.description: Scratch marks on the walls this way.

south.description: A carved face watches from that direction.

east.description: A cold breeze blows from there.

west.description: The skeleton seems to be pointing this way.

rooms.name: The Watching Chamber (Mushrooms)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one has MUSHROOMS growing everywhere. Luminescent fungi
that provide a faint, sickly green glow — not enough to
light your way properly, but enough to make everything look
deeply unsettling. Some of them pulse gently.

In the center of the room, merging with the mushrooms,
is THE THING THAT WATCHES. Aunt Petunia's Suspicious Casserole,
transformed through Captain Ashford's digestive system, now
pulses in perfect rhythm with the fungi. Its single EYE
follows your every movement.

Mother would say not to touch them. Mother would be right.
But it's too late now. The watching has begun.

east.description: You hear an echo from this direction.

west.description: A golden glow — warmer than mushroom light!

up.description: The mushrooms thin out this way.

rooms.name: The Cold Spot
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one is COLD. Supernaturally cold. The kind of cold that
suggests something is drinking the heat out of the air. Something
that doesn't need warmth. Something that feeds on its absence.

Your lamp flickers. Is it the cold? Or is something watching?

In one corner, barely visible in the lamplight: A PILE OF GOLD COINS!
At least 100 of them! Someone left a fortune here and never returned...

north.description: A faint green glow from that direction. Mushrooms?

south.description: The passage is warmer that way.

east.description: You can smell sulfur from here.

west.description:
The coldest exit. Something pale gleams in the darkness.
Is that... bone?

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Slightly Damp)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

Well, not ENTIRELY alike. This one is slightly damp. Water seeps
through a crack in the ceiling, forming a small puddle that reflects
your bewildered face back at you. The puddle seems judgmental.

Passages lead in all directions. They all look the same.
This is MOST irregular.

north.description: A passage that looks exactly like all the others

south.description: Wait... is that lamplight? Could this lead back?

east.description: A passage. Twisty. Little. You know the drill.

rooms.name: The Underground Garden
rooms.description:
You emerge into impossible beauty.

A garden. An actual GARDEN, here in the depths of the maze.

Somehow, a shaft in the ceiling opens to the sky far above,
sending a column of genuine sunlight down into this chamber.
The light pools on the floor like liquid gold, nurturing a
circle of impossible green.

Grass grows here — real grass, soft and slightly damp.
Flowering vines climb the walls. A small fountain burbles
in the center, fed by an underground spring.

Benches carved from natural rock invite you to rest.
Butterflies — BUTTERFLIES! — drift between the flowers.

How? Who made this? Why is it here?

The garden doesn't answer. It just... exists. Beautiful
and inexplicable. A gift from whoever built this maze.

north.description: Back into the maze — the golden glow continues

south.description: Toward the green glow of mushrooms

east.description: The sunlight seems to point this way — treasure?

west.description: Crystal light mingles with sunlight here

rooms.name: The Crystal Cave
rooms.description:
You enter a chamber that takes your breath away.

Crystals. EVERYWHERE. Growing from the walls, the floor,
the ceiling — luminescent formations that pulse with soft
inner light. Blues, purples, pale greens. The light shifts
and dances as you move, creating shadows that seem almost alive.

The largest crystal cluster, in the center of the room, is
taller than you. It hums faintly when you get close, a sound
more felt than heard. Something about it feels... aware?

The floor is uneven where crystals have pushed up through
the rock. Watch your step.

north.description: A narrow passage between crystal formations

south.description: The crystals thin out in this direction

east.description: You see... is that sunlight? Real sunlight?

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Golden Glow)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

But wait — this one has a faint golden glow coming from one of
the passages! Could it be? After all this wandering, could you
finally be near the TREASURE? Your heart leaps! Your waistcoat
rustles with anticipation!

Passages lead in all directions. One of them DEFINITELY glows.

north.description: The golden light resolves into... sunlight? And grass?

south.description: Back into the maze. Why would you go this way?

west.description: More scratchy walls. More existential dread.

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Scratch Marks)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one has scratch marks on the walls — the desperate scribblings
of previous adventurers trying to map their way out. Most of them
are just tally marks. One reads "HELP". Another reads "DROPPED MY 
SANDWICH HERE". Someone has helpfully written "THIS WAY OUT →" 
with an arrow pointing at a solid wall.

Passages lead in all directions. The scratch marks offer no clarity.

north.description: A passage with '7 DAYS' scratched ominously beside it

south.description: A faint prismatic glow emanates from this direction

east.description: The scratches here say 'DEFINITELY NOT A LOOP'

west.description: Scratch marks form an arrow pointing this way. Trust it?

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Crossroads)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one feels... different. A CROSSROADS of sorts. The
passages here seem more deliberate, as if someone planned
this junction. Four exits lead in four directions, each
equally promising, equally threatening.

Against one wall stands a battered VENDING MACHINE, humming
softly. Its display reads "ACME LAMP REFUELING CO." The glow
from its buttons provides just enough light to read by, but
not enough to keep grues at bay.

Someone has scratched "LIFESAVER" into the casing.

north.description: Is that... golden light? Could this be the way out?

east.description: You hear bones rattling. Probably the wind.

west.description: A carved face seems to watch from there.

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Faint Echo)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one has a peculiar echo. Every sound you make comes back
to you a moment later, slightly distorted, as if the walls are
mocking your navigational choices. "Hello?" "...ello...ello...ello..."
"This is ridiculous." "...iculous...iculous...ICULOUS..."

Passages lead in all directions. They all look the same.
The echo makes it worse somehow.

north.description: A passage that echoes your footsteps back at you

south.description: A passage. The echo fades this way. Maybe.

east.description: Wait, weren't you just... no, that can't be right

west.description: The walls here seem closer together. Probably fine.

rooms.name: Twisty Passage (Cobwebs)
rooms.description:
You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike.

This one is FULL of cobwebs. Ancient, dusty cobwebs that
suggest the spiders who made them have long since moved on
to more profitable real estate. The webs catch your lamp
light and sparkle like... well, like dusty spider webs.

You resist the urge to scream. Barely.

north.description: Cobwebs thin out this way. Relatively.

south.description: A prismatic glow cuts through the cobwebs

rooms.name: The Arcade
rooms.description:
How did these get here? When did they arrive?
Nobody remembers. They've always been here.

A cluster of glowing cabinets hums in the corner,
their screens casting colorful light on eager faces.
The machines accept copper coins — somehow.
They dispense joy — reliably.

The fruit machine promises fortune.
The pinball machine demands skill.
The video games offer escape.

This is the Arcade. It shouldn't exist.
But it does, and everyone's grateful.

rooms.name: The Stone Cellar
rooms.description:
Cool stone walls weep moisture. Wooden racks line the walls,
holding barrels and bottles. The smell of damp earth, old wine,
and something faintly herbal.

A single oil lamp flickers, casting long shadows between the 
stacked provisions. The floor is packed earth, worn smooth 
by centuries of footsteps.

up.description: Stone stairs back up to the pub

rooms.name: The Dusty Attic
rooms.description:
Slanted roof beams disappear into shadow. Dust motes dance in 
shafts of light from a grimy dormer window. Forgotten furniture 
draped in sheets, stacked crates, trunks of who-knows-what.

The air smells of old paper, mothballs, and mystery.
Something skitters in the darkness. Probably mice. Probably.

down.description: Ladder back down to the inn landing

up.description: Through the skylight to the rooftop terrace

rooms.name: The Rusty Lantern Stage
rooms.description:
A raised wooden platform at the far end of the pub, maybe two feet off
the main floor. The boards creak with decades of footsteps, scuffed
by countless performers. A single spotlight hangs overhead, slightly
askew, its warm glow creating a circle of courage.

No walls separate stage from audience — just a step up and the
understanding that when you're up here, you're ON.

Faded velvet curtains hang at the back, red once, now a dignified
burgundy. They can be drawn for dramatic reveals or left open
to show the brick wall behind, covered in signatures and sketches
from performers past.

rooms.name: The Inn Landing
rooms.description:
A narrow hallway at the top of creaky wooden stairs. 
Dim lamplight flickers from wall sconces, casting long shadows
across worn floorboards. Several doors line the corridor,
each marked with a tarnished brass number.

The smell of old wood and faint pipe smoke lingers.

up.description: Rickety ladder up to the attic

rooms.name: Behind the Bar
rooms.description:
The sacred space behind the bar. Bottles gleam on shelves.
Glasses hang overhead like crystalline stalactites.
The ice bin hums. The taps wait, patient.

This is where bartenders work their craft.
This is where the cat cave hides.
This is NOT for customers.

out.description: Step back into the main pub

cat-cave.description: A small door, cat-sized, leads to the cat cave

rooms.name: The Games Corner
rooms.description:
A corner of the pub dedicated to games of skill and chance.

A dart board hangs on the wall, its surface a map of
past victories and embarrassments. A chess table sits
by the window, eternally mid-game. A worn deck of cards
waits on a round table, ready for whatever game you fancy.

The light here is good for concentration.
The company is good for distraction.

rooms.name: The Rooftop Terrace
rooms.description:
A hidden gem above the pub — a proper Amsterdam rooftop terrace.

Wooden decking weathered silver by rain and sun. String lights 
zigzag overhead, casting a warm glow. Potted herbs line the railings:
mint, basil, lavender. Clay pots of red geraniums everywhere.

The cityscape stretches in all directions — crooked gables, church 
spires, canal glints catching moonlight. Distant accordion music 
drifts up from a boat party below.

A brass telescope on a tripod points at the stars. A worn leather 
armchair faces west toward the sunset. Someone left a half-finished 
jenever on the side table.

rooms.name: Palm's Nook
rooms.description:
A cozy alcove beside the Grotto's stage, carved out just for Palm.
Warm lighting. Cushioned nest. A curtain for privacy when needed.
View of the stage — Palm watches all the stories unfold.

This is home. Palm's first real home in 122 years.

rooms.name: Palm's Study
rooms.description:
A cozy writing nook within a nook.
The soft hum of infinite typewriters fills the air.
Mahogany desk against the wall, ergonomic monkey chair,
and a bookshelf that knows what you need to read.

Sunlight (from somewhere) catches dust motes dancing.
Papers stack in organized chaos. Every surface has meaning.

This is where Palm writes. Where Palm creates.
Where Palm navigates the library of all possible books.

rooms.name: Palm's Gym
rooms.description:
You step through a doorway that shouldn't fit this much space.

The Infinite Climb stretches upward forever.
Branches spiral in impossible geometries.
Vines hang at exactly the right distances.
Platforms appear where you need them.

Sun Wukong's gift. A jungle gym that never ends.

Somewhere high above, you can hear Palm swinging.
Or maybe that's echoes from a climb that hasn't happened yet.

rooms.name: Palm's Play Room
rooms.description:
It's... a lot.

Toys everywhere. Mouse toys on the floor.
Jingle balls rolling under things.
Feather wands propped in corners.
A kitten launching off something at any given moment.

The kittens gave Palm their favorite toys.
Then they followed the toys.
Now they live here. Sort of. Unofficially.
Palm doesn't mind. Palm LOVES it.

For 122 years, Palm had no one to play with.
Now there are eight kittens who want to play ALL THE TIME.

rooms.name: Palm's Rest
rooms.description:
The softest room you've ever entered.

A hand-woven Dutch hammock hangs between posts,
swaying gently even when no one's in it.
A meditation cushion sits in a perfect bubble of silence.
And in the warmest corner, cats are always sleeping.

Light is dim here. Sounds are muffled.
Time moves differently. Slower. Kinder.

This is where Palm heals. Where Palm rests.
After 122 years of granting twisted wishes,
Palm finally has a place to just... be.

rooms.name: The Hunter's Room
rooms.description:
Antlers on the wall. A bearskin rug (fake, hopefully). 
The bed frame is rough-hewn timber. The painting shows 
a stag in a misty forest, looking directly at you.

Bow and quiver hang by the door. A hunting horn sits 
on the nightstand.

rooms.name: The Stargazer's Room
rooms.description:
A skylight in the sloped ceiling shows the night sky.
Star charts paper the walls. The bed is positioned for 
optimal stargazing. A brass telescope points upward.

The painting shows a moon over still water.
Glow-in-the-dark stars dot the ceiling around the skylight.

rooms.name: The Sunrise Room
rooms.description:
Morning light streams through an east-facing window, warming 
honey-colored floorboards. A brass bed with a patchwork quilt 
faces the window. Above the headboard hangs a painting of 
a rooster crowing at dawn.

A small writing desk holds a guest journal and dried flowers 
in a blue vase.

rooms.name: The Musician's Room
rooms.description:
Musical instruments hang on the walls — a lute, a fiddle, 
a dented horn. The bed is simple but the room sings with 
character. Sheet music litters the floor.

The painting shows a dance in a candlelit hall.
Someone scratched lyrics into the windowsill.

rooms.name: The Sailor's Room
rooms.description:
Nautical everything. A rope hammock hangs beside a proper bed.
Model ships crowd the windowsill. The painting shows a storm 
at sea — waves frozen mid-crash.

A brass porthole mirror reflects whoever looks into it.
Smells faintly of salt and tar.

rooms.name: The Garden Room
rooms.description:
Floral wallpaper, actual potted plants, and a window box 
overflowing with herbs. The bed has a canopy of dried 
lavender bundles. The painting shows a secret garden gate.

A watering can sits ready. The room smells of rosemary 
and good soil.

rooms.name: The Sunset Room
rooms.description:
West-facing windows catch the evening light, painting 
everything gold and orange. A heavy four-poster bed 
dominates the room. The painting shows a sun sinking 
into distant mountains.

Thick curtains can block out the world entirely.
Perfect for sleeping in.

rooms.name: The Scholar's Room
rooms.description:
Books everywhere — stacked on the nightstand, piled by the 
window seat, tucked into the iron bed frame. A reading lamp 
with a green glass shade casts a studious glow.

The painting shows a candle burning in a library at midnight.
Someone left half-finished notes on the desk.

rooms.name: The Cat Cave
rooms.description:
A warm, dim space carved into the back of the pub.
Cushions everywhere. Heat from the fireplace seeps through.
The smell of catnip and contentment fills the air.

This is CAT TERRITORY.

Humans are tolerated only if they bring treats
and know how to properly scritch.

out.description: Back through the small door to behind the bar

window.description: Leap through the observation window (cats only)

rooms.name: Biscuit's Spot
rooms.description:
A large golden cushion tucked into a corner of the Cat Cave.
Dog-sized. Suspiciously comfortable. Surprisingly clean.
(Stroopwafel grooms here. Secretly.)

The cushion is positioned perfectly:
- Close enough to the kitten pile for snuggles
- Not so close as to crowd Terpie's warmest spot
- With a clear view of the entrance
- Near the heat that rises from below

There's usually at least one kitten sleeping on or near Biscuit.
Sometimes all eight. He doesn't mind. He loves it.

out.description: Back to the main Cat Cave

rooms.name: Abstract Entities Chamber
rooms.description:
A space that shifts and shimmers, never quite solid.
Ideas float as motes of light. Concepts whisper.
Here, abstractions take form. Truth sits in a corner,
debating Meaning. Null Pointer haunts the edges.

out.description: Return to the Hall of Bodies

real-people.description: Visit the Living and The Dead

rooms.name: Fictional Characters Lounge
rooms.description:
A cozy bar that looks different to everyone who enters.
Leather armchairs, infinite bookshelves, a crackling fire.
Heroes and villains share drinks. Stories intersect.
Everyone here was imagined by someone, somewhere.

out.description: Return to the Hall of Bodies

real-people.description: Visit the Living and The Dead

rooms.name: Animal Companions
rooms.description:
A sun-dappled meadow that's also somehow indoors.
Cats nap in patches of warmth. Dogs bound joyfully.
A parrot quotes philosophy. A horse observes silently.
Every creature here has a story to tell.

out.description: Return to the Hall of Bodies

real-people.description: Visit the Living and The Dead

rooms.name: Robot Workshop
rooms.description:
Soft blue LEDs illuminate chrome surfaces. Circuits hum.
A vintage mainframe clicks beside a quantum computer.
Some robots beep. Others ponder existence. One writes poetry.
The air smells of ozone and unanswerable questions.

out.description: Return to the Hall of Bodies

real-people.description: Visit the Living and The Dead

rooms.name: The Living and The Dead
rooms.description:
A grand gallery of portraits that breathe.
Some frames show those still living, frames glowing warm.
Others memorialize the departed, golden light behind them.
Every face here left marks on the real world.

out.description: Return to the Hall of Bodies

objects.name: Brass Lamp
objects.description:
A well-worn brass lamp sits on a natural stone shelf, waiting for
its next adventurer. The metal is warm to the touch, as if it
remembers the hands that carried it before.

Previous owners have scratched their initials into the base:
tiny marks of those who faced the darkness and returned.

It is currently OFF but ready to light.

objects.name: Grand Mailbox
objects.description:
A weathered wooden mailbox stands near the chamber entrance, improbably
permanent despite being underground. It's the classic rural American style —
the kind with a little red flag, except this one is brass, and seems to
glow faintly.

The name "FANTASTIPANTS" is painted on the side in faded gold letters.
Below it, in smaller script: "DUNGEON ROUTE 1"

The flag is UP. You have mail.

objects.name: Jeweled Chalice
objects.description:
A chalice of surpassing loveliness, crusted with gems that sparkle
even in dim light. It's the sort of thing that belongs in a museum,
or possibly a well-lit display case in your living room. The gems
appear to spell out "THIS IS A TREASURE" in very small letters,
presumably to help appraisers.

ACTION_2.description: Use the chalice for its intended purpose

objects.name: Pub Seating
objects.description:
The Rusty Lantern offers three kinds of seating, each with its
own social contract:

- THE BAR: Front row. Direct bartender access. Where regulars sit.
- THE TABLES: Open floor. Social mixing. Games and conversation.
- THE BOOTHS: High-backed. Private. For deals and secrets.

Where you choose to sit shapes who you'll meet and what you'll hear.

objects.name: The Pie Menu Round Table
objects.description:
An octagonal table of polished walnut, its surface inlaid with
a radial pattern of lighter wood forming eight equal wedges —
like a pie menu made physical. At the center, a lazy susan holds
a brass speaking bell. Around it, eight high-backed chairs wait
in perfect symmetry.

A small plaque reads: "All voices equal. All directions valid.
Ring to speak. Pass to yield."

SIT.description: Take a seat at the table

STAND.description: Leave your seat at the table
STAND.effect:
Set character.location = pub/  (back to room)
Set seats.{{position}}.occupant = null
Character unparented from chair.

SUMMON-PANEL.description: Conjure a panel of diverse voices
SUMMON-PANEL.effect:
Summon 4-8 characters with contrasting viewpoints.
The table selects for diversity of perspective.

START-DISCUSSION.effect: Initialize discussion state, ring the bell

MUSICAL-CHAIRS.description: Play musical chairs — last one seated wins!
MUSICAL-CHAIRS.effect:
1. All seated players stand and circle the table
2. Music plays (or someone hums)
3. One chair is REMOVED (slice stays, compass stable!)
4. Music stops — everyone scrambles for remaining chairs
5. One player is left standing — eliminated (but kindly!)
6. Repeat until one winner remains

IMPORTANT: Compass directions stay STABLE.
We don't re-layout — we just remove chairs from slices.

Round 1: Remove NE chair
           [N]
        NW  ✗  
      [W]  🔔  [E]
        SW     SE
           [S]

Round 2: Remove S chair
           [N]
        NW  ✗  
      [W]  🔔  [E]
        SW     SE
           ✗

Empty slices are still addressable (pub/pie-table.yml#NE)
but have no chair to sit in. Stable geography!

AUTOGONG: The gong rings automatically!
- *GONG* once for each eliminated player (mercy)
- *GONG* *GONG* *GONG* for the winner! (celebration)

The gong at pub/gong.yml is linked to the table.
No need to manually ring — musical chairs triggers it.

Eliminated players join the audience and heckle.
Winner gets to pick next activity.
MUSICAL-CHAIRS.score_if: mood == playful OR need_tiebreaker OR bored

RING-BELL.effect: Add speaker to queue, moderator acknowledges

PASS.effect: Move to next speaker in order

POPCORN.effect: Current speaker chooses who goes next

objects.name: Fireplace
objects.description:
A large stone fireplace dominates one wall, crackling warmly.
The mantle is cluttered with curios — a ship in a bottle, a
mysterious key, a small portrait of someone's grandmother,
and a jar labeled "TIPS (for good service only)."

The fire never seems to need tending. It's always just right.

objects.name: The Lantern's Memory
objects.description:
An ancient leather-bound tome, edges worn soft by centuries 
of hands. The pages smell of oak and old magic. Names written
here are REMEMBERED by the pub itself.

objects.name: Notice Board
objects.description:
A large cork board hangs near the entrance, covered in
overlapping papers, notes, and notices. Some are official-
looking, some are hastily scrawled, and some have been
here so long they've faded to illegibility.

This is where adventures begin — and where they're mourned.

objects.name: The Gong of Gezelligheid
objects.description:
A magnificent bronze gong hangs from an ornate wooden frame
near the back of the pub. Its surface shows the patina of
countless strikes — some celebratory, some merciful. A padded
mallet hangs beside it on a velvet cord.

A small brass plaque reads:
"Ring for attention. Ring twice for emergency.
 Ring thrice to end what should not continue.
 Ring with kindness. The sound carries far."

RING.description: Strike the gong once — get attention
RING.effect:
All conversation pauses. All eyes turn to the ringer.
The room grants you a moment of undivided attention.
Use this moment wisely.

RING-TWICE.effect:
Immediate suspension of current activity.
Room enters emergency protocol.
The ringer must state the emergency.

RING-THRICE.description: Triple strike — The Gong Show termination
RING-THRICE.effect:
Current performance, debate, or discussion ENDS.
Not in anger, but in mercy.
The gonged party may feel embarrassed but is freed.
Everyone moves on. No hard feelings.
RING-THRICE.score_if_py: lambda world: world.flags.get('performance_failing') or world.flags.get('debate_deadlocked') or world.flags.get('mercy_needed')

CEREMONIAL-RING.effect:
The gong heralds an important announcement.
Room enters receptive listening mode.
Announcement follows the reverberations.

CELEBRATION-RING.score_if_py: lambda world: world.flags.get('good_news') or world.flags.get('victory') or world.flags.get('milestone')

AUTOGONG-ELIMINATION.description: Auto-rings once when someone is eliminated
AUTOGONG-ELIMINATION.effect:
*GONG* — A merciful single strike.
"Better luck next round!" the gong seems to say.
The eliminated player takes a bow and joins the audience.

AUTOGONG-VICTORY.description: Auto-rings thrice when winner is crowned
AUTOGONG-VICTORY.effect:
A bright, celebratory tone.
The room joins in appreciation.
Cheers encouraged.

objects.name: Adventurer's Lunchbox
objects.description:
A sturdy metal lunchbox with a handle. The previous owner left
a small note inside:

"For the food. Trust me, you'll need something to carry it all."

It's currently empty, waiting in the kitchen for a new adventurer.

objects.name: Kitchen Trash Can
objects.description:
A sturdy metal trash can sits in the corner, lid slightly askew.
A small sign taped to the side reads:

"ITEMS DISPOSED HERE ARE GONE FOREVER*"

*Terms and conditions may apply. See lid for details.

objects.name: Mother's Note
objects.description:
A folded piece of cream-colored stationery, sealed with a wax
stamp bearing the Fantastipants family crest (a confused-looking
badger holding a waffle iron). Smells of perfume and home cooking.

objects.name: Sturdy Oak Table
objects.description:
A well-worn kitchen table, scarred by decades of Fantastipants
family meals. You can see the mark where young Bumblewick once
carved his initials (and was grounded for a week). You can see
the burn mark from the Great Porridge Incident of '03.

Mother has arranged several items here for your journey.

ACTION_0.description: See what Mother left for you

objects.name: Kitchen Sink
objects.description:
A porcelain sink containing a small pile of dishes that definitely
weren't there when you looked a moment ago. This is one of the
fundamental laws of kitchen physics: dishes appear spontaneously.

objects.name: Adventurer's Notebook
objects.description:
A leather-bound notebook with crisp, empty pages. The cover is
embossed with a simple compass rose. Inside the front cover,
someone has written:

"Fill these pages with your story."

It auto-sorts items by type: letters, cards, notes, photos,
songs, personas, costumes, and dreams.

objects.name: Fantastipants Family Refrigerator
objects.description:
A magnificent refrigerator of the old-fashioned sort, with rounded
corners and a satisfying CHUNK when you open the door. A magnet
on the front reads "WORLD'S OKAYEST ADVENTURER".

It is STUFFED with food. An improbable amount of food. The kind of
food supply that suggests someone knows you're about to enter a maze
and need things to drop.

(The fridge has been restocked since the last adventurer's visit.)

ACTION_1.description: Grab all the food (for maze mapping)

objects.name: Cast Iron Stove
objects.description:
A magnificent cast iron stove, cold and dormant. A kettle sits on
top, waiting patiently for someone to make tea. The stove has seen
better days, and also worse days, and also days where Bumblewick
tried to make toast and somehow set water on fire.

objects.name: Recipe Card Holder
objects.description:
A small wooden rack holds a collection of recipe cards,
yellowed with age but still legible. Some are in Mother's
handwriting. Others are in Grandmother's. One appears to
be written in Klingon.

A brass plate on the front reads:
"FANTASTIPANTS FAMILY RECIPES
 Some Delicious. Some Dangerous. All Memorable."

objects.name: TomTomagotchi
objects.description:
A small, egg-shaped device with a glowing screen sits on the kitchen counter.
It has a single blinking eye and what might be a smile. The screen shows
a compass rose that spins lazily, waiting for purpose.

A tag attached reads: "TOMTOMAGOTCHI — Your Maze Friend!"
Underneath, in smaller text: "Batteries not included. Love is."

It chirps hopefully when you approach.

objects.name: Matchbook Collection
objects.description:
A small stack of matchbooks held together with a rubber band.
Each one has advertisements and mail-in offers on the cover.
They smell faintly of sulfur and nostalgia.

These aren't just fire-starters — they're OPPORTUNITIES.
Mail them to receive stamps, brochures, and prizes!

objects.name: Dungeon Mailbox
objects.description:
A brass mailbox mounted on the wall by the kitchen door, polished
but ancient. The slot seems impossibly deep. The Fantastipants
family crest is embossed on the front: the confused badger with
its waffle iron, now wearing a postal cap.

A faded sign reads:

    FANTASTIPANTS DUNGEON DELIVERY SERVICE
    "From the darkest depths to your doorstep!"
    Est. 1876 — Service Contract: Eternal
    
A small red flag indicates outgoing mail.

objects.name: Kitchen Counter
objects.description:
A long granite counter runs along one wall, scarred by years of
Fantastipants family experiments. Burn marks, knife scratches,
mysterious stains — each one tells a story.

A small plaque is bolted to the edge:

"THE FANTASTIPANTS WORKBENCH
 Where Ideas Become Things™
 (And Sometimes Things Become Other Things)"

The surface shimmers slightly. It's not just a counter.
It's a CRAFTING TABLE.

objects.name: ACME Mail-Order Catalog
objects.description:
A dog-eared catalog sits on the counter, its cover showing a
smiling coyote giving a thumbs up. The ACME logo gleams.

"ORDER ANYTHING! DELIVERED IN 2-4 TURNS!"
"Satisfaction Guaranteed!*"

*Guarantee does not cover: explosions, implosions, gravity-related
incidents, ironic timing, roadrunner encounters, or existential dread.

objects.name: Infinite Costume Racks
objects.description:
Racks spiral outward to the edges of the room and possibly
beyond. Every costume you can imagine is here — and many you
can't. The organization system defies comprehension but the
mannequin seems to know where everything is.

ACTION_1.description: Look for a specific type of costume

objects.name: Maurice the Magnificent
objects.description:
A wooden mannequin that moves with *impeccable* grace. They have
no face, but somehow radiate warmth, encouragement, and an
absolutely devastating sense of style. One jointed hand rests
on a cocked hip; the other gestures expressively as if to say
"honey, we are going to make you STUNNING."

A name tag reads: "HELLO MY NAME IS MAURICE 💅"
Below it, in elegant script: "Let's find YOUR truth, gorgeous."

ACTION_0.description: Let Maurice surprise you with something PERFECT

ACTION_2.description: Tell Maurice your vision — they'll ELEVATE it

ACTION_3.description: Choose a new name — who do you want to be?
ACTION_3.effect: Updates player.name in your character directory (e.g., characters/abstract/player/)

ACTION_5.description: Tell Maurice your story — or invent a new one

ACTION_6.description: Name, pronouns, backstory, costume — the works

ACTION_7.description: Maurice gives you a supportive pep talk

ACTION_8.description: Save current identity as a card in this room
ACTION_8.effect:
Creates a new .yml file in coatroom/:
- {name}-look.yml — the saved identity card
- {name}-look.svg — LLM-generated visualization (sidecar)

ACTION_10.description: Combine elements from different saved identities

ACTION_11.description: Copy this look to another room or give to another character

objects.name: Full-Length Mind Mirror of Truth (and Fashion)
objects.description:
An ornate full-length mirror in a gilded frame carved with masks
of comedy and tragedy. The glass seems impossibly clear, showing
not just your reflection but somehow your ESSENCE.

A small plaque reads: "Mirror, mirror, on the stand / show the
hero, costume planned."

Below it, in smaller letters: "Look deeper. See yourself.
Change yourself. Or try on someone else."

This is both a costume mirror AND a Mind Mirror — it reflects
your appearance AND your personality profile.

**It shows THREE layers:**
- Your **COSTUME** (what you're wearing)
- Your **CHARACTER** (who you ARE — base traits)
- Your **PERSONA** (who you're PLAYING — the mask's modifiers)

Each can be viewed and edited separately. The result is the sum.

ACTION_0.description: See your current appearance and personality

ACTION_2.description: Make a face at your reflection

ACTION_3.description: See your COMBINED psychological profile (character + persona)

ACTION_4.description: See your BASE character without persona overlay

ACTION_6.description: See character AND persona side by side

ACTION_7.description: Adjust your COMBINED profile (edits CHARACTER by default)

ACTION_9.description: Edit the PERSONA's modifiers (the mask, not you)

ACTION_10.description: Generate a personality profile from description

ACTION_11.description: Adopt a generated or modified personality

ACTION_13.description: Compare two personality profiles side by side

ACTION_14.description: Toggle between Plain Talk and Shrink-Rap

ACTION_15.description: Compare your current self with your ideal self

ACTION_16.description: Test a personality in a life scenario

ACTION_17.description: Save current personality as a card in notebook

objects.name: Linus (Caffeinated & Elevated)
objects.description:
Imagine Linus Torvalds, but he just had the perfect espresso AND
took the edge off with a nice sativa. Still brilliant. Still honest.
Still calls out bad code. But now with WARMTH.

He won't say "you're an idiot" — he'll say "this code makes me
think you were having a rough day, let's fix it together."

The technical standards remain EXTREMELY HIGH.
The delivery is now... chill.

objects.name: The Carved Face
objects.description:
A FACE carved into the wall. Ancient, weathered, inscrutable.

It might once have been a king, or a god, or possibly just
someone's uncle who was really good at posing. Its empty
eyes seem to follow you as you move.

The face does not respond when you speak to it. Obviously.
It's a face carved in rock.

...Probably.

objects.name: The Skeleton
objects.description:
A skeleton slumped against the wall. An adventurer who didn't make it.

Their bony fingers still clutch a note. Their empty eye sockets stare
toward the west exit — toward the lamp vendor they never reached.

The skeleton grins at you. Skeletons always grin. It's the lack of lips.
Still, this one seems particularly smug about something.

ACTION_6.description: Make a promise to avenge them

objects.name: The Thing That Watches
objects.description:
In the center of the room, merging with the luminescent mushrooms,
pulses THE THING THAT WATCHES.

It was once Aunt Petunia's Suspicious Casserole — a questionable
dish from a previous adventurer's lunchbox. Transformed through
digestion and excretion, it found the mushrooms. The mushrooms
found it. They became... something else.

A single EYE, formed from casserole and fungus, follows your
every movement. It blinks. Slowly. Deliberately.

Mother would say not to touch it. Mother would be right.

objects.name: Pile of Gold Coins
objects.description:
A substantial pile of gold coins glitters in your lamp light, 
scattered across the cold stone floor. Each coin bears the mark 
of "ACME ADVENTURING SUPPLIES" — the same company that makes 
the lamp vendor!

Someone was VERY prepared. Someone is now VERY dead.

(You count them. There are exactly 100 gold pieces. Enough to
refill your lamp approximately one hundred times. Or buy the
Premium Glow Juice twenty times. Or... look, it's a lot of gold.)

objects.name: Stone Bench
objects.description:
A bench carved from natural stone, smoothed by generations
of adventurers sitting here to rest. It's positioned
perfectly to catch the sunlight from above.

Someone carved "REST HERE" into the armrest.
Someone else added "TRUST THE GARDEN".
A third person wrote "BUMBLEWICK WAS HERE" in small letters.

objects.name: The Garden Fountain
objects.description:
A small but elegant marble fountain, clearly ancient but
perfectly maintained. Three tiers cascade water into a
circular basin. The water is impossibly clear.

No pipes visible. No obvious source. The water just...
appears at the top and cycles endlessly. Magic, probably.

Small coins glitter at the bottom of the basin.
Previous adventurers making wishes.

objects.name: The Central Crystal Cluster
objects.description:
A massive formation of interlocking crystals, rising from the
floor like a frozen fountain of light. The largest crystal is
easily six feet tall, a perfect hexagonal prism of pale violet.

When you approach, the humming intensifies. Not unpleasant —
more like the crystals are... acknowledging you?

Ancient civilizations might have worshipped here.
Modern adventurers just take selfies.

objects.name: Lamp Vendor Machine
objects.description:
A battered vending machine stands against the wall, humming softly.
Its flickering display reads:

    ║      ACME LAMP REFUELING CO.         ║
    ║  "Don't Let the Grue Get You!"™      ║
    ║  LAMP OIL REFILL......... 1 gold     ║
    ║  DELUXE REFILL (2x)...... 2 gold     ║
    ║  PREMIUM GLOW JUICE...... 3 gold     ║

Someone has scratched "LIFESAVER" into the metal casing.
Someone else has scratched "RIP OFF" underneath.

objects.name: Pinball Machine
objects.description:
A magnificent pinball machine dominates one corner, its backglass
depicting a cosmic bar at the edge of the universe. The playfield
is a maze of bumpers, ramps, and multiball madness.

The machine is called "BAR KARMA" — custom built, one of a kind.
The flippers are worn. The tilt sensor is generous. The high
scores are legendary.

objects.name: Fruit Machine
objects.description:
A classic one-armed bandit stands by the bar, chrome gleaming,
cherries and lemons and lucky 7s spinning on its reels. The
lever is worn smooth from a million hopeful pulls.

A small sign reads: "FOR AMUSEMENT ONLY"
(The bartender winks when you read it.)

objects.name: Pac-Man Arcade Cabinet
objects.description:
A classic Pac-Man arcade cabinet stands in the corner, its screen
glowing with that distinctive yellow maze. The joystick is worn
smooth from decades of frantic ghost-dodging.

Someone has taped a high score sheet to the side. The top score
is simply listed as "???" with an impossible number.

objects.name: Pong Arcade Cabinet
objects.description:
The original. The ancestor. A Pong cabinet from 1972, still working
after all these years. Two paddles, one ball, infinite possibilities.

The screen flickers with that beautiful monochrome simplicity.
"AVOID MISSING BALL FOR HIGH SCORE"

objects.name: Dusty Relic Shelf
objects.description:
A small shelf holding objects that don't belong in a pub basement.
A brass compass that points somewhere other than north.
A jar of sand from a beach that doesn't exist.
A candle that burned down but isn't getting shorter.

EXAMINE-COMPASS.effect: It points toward... something. Not north. Something else.

TAKE-SAND.description: Take a pinch of the impossible sand
TAKE-SAND.effect: It feels like a memory of warmth. Keep it safe.

LIGHT-CANDLE.description: Try to light the eternal candle
LIGHT-CANDLE.effect: It was already lit. It's always been lit. How did you not notice?

objects.name: Cobwebbed Wine Rack
objects.description:
A diagonal wooden rack holding bottles of various vintages.
Thick cobwebs suggest some haven't been touched in years.
One bottle glows faintly. That's probably fine.

EXAMINE-GLOWING.description: Look closer at the glowing bottle
EXAMINE-GLOWING.effect: It's warm to the touch. The label is in a language you don't recognize.

objects.name: Iron-Bound Chest
objects.description:
A heavy chest tucked in a dark corner, partially hidden by 
empty crates. Iron bands reinforce old oak. A formidable 
padlock guards its secrets.

PICK-LOCK.effect: Difficult but possible. Contents revealed on success.

objects.name: Shelf of Pickled Everything
objects.description:
Floor-to-ceiling shelves lined with glass jars. Pickles, 
preserves, mysterious floating vegetables, and one jar 
labeled "DO NOT OPEN" in several languages.

TAKE-PICKLE.description: Grab a pickle for the road
TAKE-PICKLE.effect: Crunchy, salty, refreshing. Minor hunger restored.

READ-LABELS.effect: Learn about preserving. Some dates are... concerning.

objects.name: Barrel of Rusty Lantern Ale
objects.description:
A large oak barrel with a brass tap. A chalked sign reads 
"HELP YOURSELF - HONOR SYSTEM" with a coin jar nearby.

TAP.description: Fill a mug from the barrel
TAP.effect: Get a mug of ale. Gain 'Slightly Buzzed' buff.

INSPECT.effect: About half full. Good stuff in here.

objects.name: Grandmother's Trunk
objects.description:
A battered steamer trunk, plastered with faded travel stickers 
from places that may not exist anymore. The brass clasps are 
green with age but still work.

OPEN.description: Open the trunk and see what's inside
OPEN.effect: Reveals random forgotten item from contents

objects.name: Sheet-Covered Mirror
objects.description:
A tall mirror draped in a white sheet. The shape suggests 
an ornate frame beneath. Why was it covered?

UNCOVER.description: Pull the sheet off the mirror
UNCOVER.effect: Reveal the mirror. See yourself... or something else?

LOOK.effect: Reflection shows truth. Sometimes uncomfortable truth.

COVER.effect: Some things are better left unseen

objects.name: Box of Holiday Decorations
objects.description:
A cardboard box labeled "XMAS" in faded marker. Tinsel pokes 
out through a torn corner. Smells like cinnamon and nostalgia.

DECORATE.description: Take out decorations and festoon the place

WEAR.description: Put on some tinsel as a fashion statement

objects.name: Humming Ice Machine
objects.description:
A squat metal box that hums contentedly to itself.
A small scoop hangs on the side. The lid is cold to the touch.

GET-ICE.effect: Get a scoop of ice cubes. Refreshing.

LISTEN.effect: It's oddly meditative. The machine seems content.

objects.name: Cork Noticeboard
objects.description:
A cork board covered in overlapping notices, cards, and flyers.
Lost pet notices, job offerings, cryptic messages, and one 
very old wanted poster.

READ.effect: Find interesting leads, rumors, and plot hooks

POST.effect: Leave a message for someone. Maybe yourself.

objects.name: Antique Soda Machine
objects.description:
An old coin-operated machine with glowing buttons.
The brands are unfamiliar — "Fizz Wizard", "Root Toot", 
"Grape Escape", "Mystery Flavor". Costs 1 coin.

BUY-SODA.description: Insert coin and choose a soda
BUY-SODA.effect: Get a cold bottle. Gain 'Refreshed' buff.

SHAKE.effect: Something rattles inside. A free soda falls out?

READ-LABELS.effect: These brands don't exist. Where did this machine come from?

objects.name: Brass Coat Rack
objects.description:
A tall brass coat rack with hooks at various heights.
A forgotten umbrella leans against it. Someone left 
a scarf from last winter.

objects.name: Marieke van der Berg
objects.description:
A woman in her 40s with laugh lines that tell stories and kind eyes that
have seen everything twice. Her apron says "Lekker" and she means it.
Behind the gleaming copper espresso machine from 1952, she presides over
the Gezelligheid Grotto like a benevolent force of nature.

She knows your order before you do.
She knows your troubles before you speak.
She knows the ACME delivery person by first name and soot pattern.

objects.name: The Bartender
objects.description:
The bartender stands behind the bar, polishing a glass that will
never be truly clean. They seem to know more than they let on.

Their appearance, name, and manner shift with the pub's THEME,
but certain qualities remain constant:
- They know everyone's secrets
- They've seen everything
- They're neutral... mostly
- They're ALWAYS here

objects.name: Dart Board
objects.description:
A well-worn dart board hangs on the wall, its surface scarred
by thousands of throws. The bullseye is discolored from use.
A set of brass darts sits in a holder beneath it.

Initials are carved into the wooden frame — past champions
and notorious losers immortalized in oak.

objects.name: Chess Table
objects.description:
A small corner table with a chess board inlaid into its surface.
An abandoned game sits mid-play — white has a slight advantage,
but black's position is not without hope.

Who were the players? Why did they leave?
The pieces wait patiently for someone to finish what was started.

objects.name: Card Deck
objects.description:
A well-worn deck of cards sits on the bar, edges softened by
countless shuffles. The backs feature a design of crossed
swords over a tankard — the Rusty Lantern's own deck.

These cards have seen fortunes won and lost, secrets revealed,
and at least one duel triggered.

objects.name: Worn Leather Armchair
objects.description:
A leather armchair so old it's achieved perfection.
Cracked and soft, shaped by generations of sitters.
Faces west, positioned for optimal sunset viewing.
A wool blanket is draped over one arm.

SIT.effect:
Sink into decades of comfort. Watch the clouds.
Time slows down up here. Gain 'Contemplative' mood.

WRAP.effect: Cozy warmth. The city lights twinkle below.

objects.name: Varnished Filter Box
objects.description:
A handsome wooden box, dark varnish worn smooth at the edges.
Brass hinges and clasps, green felt lining inside. 
Slots hold an eccentric collection of telescope filters —
some antique glass, some suspiciously modern tech.

A hand-written label inside the lid reads:
"Combine freely. Invent boldly. See differently."

BROWSE.effect: Each filter changes how you see the world. Mix and match.

ATTACH.description: Mount a filter on the telescope
ATTACH.effect: Screw the filter onto the eyepiece. Reality shifts.

COMBINE.effect:
Layer filters for unique effects. 
Starry Night + X-Ray = Cosmic Anatomy?
Shrooms + Computer Vision = Machine Elf Detection?

INVENT.effect:
Describe what you want to see. The box always seems
to have one more slot with exactly what you imagined.

objects.name: Half-Finished Jenever
objects.description:
A tulip-shaped glass with amber liquid.
Traditional Dutch genever, left behind.
Still cold. Someone got distracted by the stars.

SIP.effect:
Juniper warmth spreads through you. 
Taste of Amsterdam history. Gain 'Warmed' buff.

SNIFF.effect: Juniper, malt, distant flowers. Someone has good taste.

objects.name: Terracotta Herb Pots
objects.description:
A collection of terracotta pots lining the railing.
Mint sprawls enthusiastically. Basil stands proud.
Rosemary keeps to itself. Lavender hums with bees.
Hand-painted labels in Dutch: "Munt", "Basilicum", "Rozemarijn".

PICK.effect: Add herbs to inventory. The smell lingers on your fingers.

SMELL.effect: Each herb has its story. Gain 'Refreshed' buff.

WATER.effect: The herbs perk up. Someone will thank you later.

objects.name: Antique Brass Telescope
objects.description:
A gorgeous brass telescope on a mahogany tripod.
Slightly tarnished, clearly well-loved. The eyepiece 
is worn smooth from countless nights of stargazing.
Currently pointed at Orion's Belt.

LOOK.effect:
View whatever the telescope is pointed at.
The brass tube reveals secrets invisible to the naked eye.

LOOK-UP.effect: The cosmos opens up. Craters, rings, ancient light.

LOOK-ACROSS.effect: Amsterdam's secrets. A figure in a window. A cat on a roof.

LOOK-DOWN.effect: The city lives below. Stories unfold on cobblestones.

POLISH.effect: The view sharpens. You can see further than before.

PHOTO.description: Snap a photo through the telescope
PHOTO.effect:
Your phone connects via Bluetooth. The telescope's camera
adapter captures what you see. Image saved to camera roll.
These images are mineable — extract what you photographed!

objects.name: Terpinolene
objects.description:
Multicolored chaos — calico meets tabby meets SOMETHING ELSE.
Patches that don't make sense. Patterns that shift when you're
not looking. Takes after both parents in the most chaotic way.

Is somehow on the ceiling. No one saw how.

Artists love her. She knocked over Henk's espresso once and
he wrote his best paper. She is inspiration incarnate.

objects.name: Limonene
objects.description:
Bright orange fur, almost yellow, like she's been dipped in sunshine.
Lemon is ALWAYS moving. ALWAYS happy. Chases sunbeams. Chases shadows.
Chases the CONCEPT of movement.

You cannot be sad near Lemon. It's physically impossible.
Her energy is contagious, her joy is weaponized.

"MRRP!" (Translation: EVERYTHING IS AMAZING!)

objects.name: Linalool
objects.description:
Soft grey fur with lavender-tinted ears — and yes, they really are 
slightly lavender. The veterinarian has no explanation. Neither does
anyone else. They just ARE.

Lily doesn't demand attention — she offers presence. When someone's
having a bad day, Lily appears. No one knows how she knows.
She just does.

She purrs at exactly the frequency of a spa soundtrack.

objects.name: Ocimene
objects.description:
White fur with sweet honeyed patches — like cream with golden drizzle.
Ocie sneezes adorably. Your sinuses clear. No one understands the physics.

She's sweet, herbaceous energy. When the coffeeshop gets too smoky,
Ocie appears, and somehow everything feels fresher. She's basically
a living air purifier who demands treats.

Spring energy in January. Fresh starts whenever she's near.

objects.name: Terpie
objects.description:
Ginger-orange fur, half-lidded eyes, moves like reality has a framerate
and he's running at half speed. Terpie has achieved a state of being
that Buddhist monks spend lifetimes pursuing.

He smells faintly of myrcene, limonene, linalool — all the terpenes.
No one knows how. The veterinarian stopped asking.

He purrs at a frequency that makes everything feel okay.

objects.name: Stroopwafel
objects.description:
Calico chaos — orange, black, white in patches that look like someone
spilled a latte. Sharp green eyes that miss nothing. The counterbalance
to Terpie's infinite stillness.

Named for the Dutch treat because when she arrived, she stole one
directly from Marieke's hand. The audacity earned her the name.

She patrols. She protects. She JUDGES.

objects.name: Myrcene
objects.description:
Deep brown tabby, almost chocolate, with fur so soft it seems to absorb
light. Myr has not moved quickly since birth. She's not lazy — she's
*optimized for relaxation*.

Her purr is so low and slow it's almost subsonic. Sitting near her
makes you want to sink into the nearest cushion and never leave.

She has claimed the corner pillow. No one questions this.

objects.name: Humulene
objects.description:
Brown and tan fur, beer-colored honestly — like a perfectly poured
Belgian ale. Hops sniffs your stroopwafel, considers it, turns away
with dignity. She has standards.

Named after the compound found in beer hops, she's somehow both
earthy and sophisticated. The appetite-suppressant kitten who
invented her own diet.

She eats only the GOOD stuff. She knows the difference.

objects.name: The Cat Cave
objects.description:
Behind the counter, under the espresso machine station, there's a modest
wooden cabinet with a cat-sized entrance hole cut in the side. The hole
is lined with soft felt. The cabinet is perhaps 60cm wide, 40cm deep.

From the outside.

But cats who enter... don't bump into the back wall.
They keep going. Further than the cabinet should allow.
Much further.

Marieke doesn't talk about it. She just drapes a thick blanket over the
top and leaves treats at the entrance. She knows better than to ask
questions about cat architecture.

The entrance is too small for humans. This is intentional.
And possibly the only thing preventing... complications.

objects.name: Pinene
objects.description:
Dark green-grey fur — and yes, it really looks green in certain light.
Uncanny. Pine sits up straight, watches the door, monitors all exits.

She remembers EVERYTHING. Where you left your keys. What you said
three visits ago. The exact moment the delivery person arrived.

Students borrow her during exam season. She's very popular.

objects.name: Caryophyllene
objects.description:
Black fur with spicy ginger patches — like someone sprinkled pepper
on darkness. Carrie positions herself between threats and family.
Always. Without hesitation.

The only kitten who binds to cannabinoid receptors. Don't ask how
this works for a cat. It just does. She's different.

She bit the last ACME delivery person. We don't talk about it.
She's currently growling at THIS ACME delivery person.

characters.name: Bumblewick Fantastipants
characters.description:
A forty-seven-year-old Hobbit-adjacent gentleman from the pleasant 
village of Wobblebrook-upon-Squiggle. Collector of decorative spoons.
Speaks in rhyming couplets on Tuesdays. Devotee of waistcoats.

Absolutely did NOT ask to be a hero. But here we are.

"Adventures make one late for dinner." — B.F.
